data.title: Administration •
data.text:
The Clerk-Treasurer is an elected official who is serves a four-year term and must live within the town boundaries. The Town of Centerville Clerk-Treasurer is Sarah Rice. Email

The Clerk-Treasurer manages the town’s general and operating funds. This office is responsible for investing, managing, and analyzing these funds. All funds are invested in securities that comply with the State Board of Accounts approved investment policies and adhere to state laws.

Duties of the Clerk

Administer dog tags

Administer vendor permits

Administer garage sale permits

Attend meetings of the Town Council, Board of Zoning Appeals, and Planning Commission

Maintain the town website

Oversee the duties of the utility office

Prepare agendas

Prepare Resolutions

Prepare some Ordinances

Provide Notary Public services

Publicize legal notices

Record minutes and maintain all town documents

Duties of the Treasurer

Generate and record receipts and disbursements

Investment of excess funds

Liaison with banks and brokerages

Prepare town budgets

Reporting and reconciliation

The Planning and Zoning Department is governed by a board that will oversee the zoning regulations to protect properties and the rights of other property owners.

Meetings

7 p.m.

Third Tuesday of the month – upon request

Municipal Building

204 E Main St.

Centerville, IN 47330

To set up a meeting with the Zoning Board, you may contact the office of the Building Commissioner at 765-855-5515

Members

Marvin Esham

Greg White

Marilyn Buchholz

Jason Hinshaw

Overview

The Town of Centerville’s Board of Zoning Appeals helps with the zoning of parcels within the town boundaries.

Property owners that have a need to use a property that is not zoned for a particular purpose may come to the Zoning Board and appeal for a variance. In this case, all adjacent property owners are notified of the date, time, location, and purpose of the meeting and are encouraged to attend. If the variance is approved, the approval does not carry over with the property if it is sold. The approval becomes void if not used within one year.
